p.em: Dont forget the constant of integration. Do not use scripts on the constant (e.g., c_2).

webwork-reps.pg:
############################################# ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2026-01-02T11:05:17-05:00 ### A recent stable commit (2022-07-01): ### 6c761d3dba23af92cba35001c852aac04ae99a5f ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ############################################# ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1() ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1() ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(6) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "PGML.pl", "niceTables.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "contextForm.pl", "PGcourse.pl", ); COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt'); COMMENT('Solve a separable DE using separation of variables.');
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup Code ############################################################ Context()->variables->add(y => 'Real'); Context()->variables->add(c => 'Real'); $order = 1; $f = Formula("1+cos(x)"); $g = Formula("y"); $g_inv = Formula("1/y"); $F = Formula("x+sin(x)"); $G = Formula("ln|y|"); $y_gen = Formula("c*e^(x+sin(x))");
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML Solve each of the following differential equations using the separation of variables method. Press [|Activate|]* to submit your answers and get instant feedback.
Give the order and separable form:
>> [@DataTable( [ [PGML('[`_{}`]'), ], [PGML('[`\text{order:}`]'), PGML('[_]{$order}{5}'), PGML(''), PGML('[`\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = `]'), PGML('[_]{$f}{10}'), PGML('[_]{$g}{10}'), ], [PGML('[`_{}`]'), ], ], align => 'r', valign => 'middle',);@]* <<
Separate variables and integrate to both sides:
>> [@DataTable( [ [PGML('[`_{}`]'), ], [PGML('[`\displaystyle\int`]'), PGML('[_]{$g_inv}{10}'), PGML('[`\displaystyle dy = \int `]'), PGML('[_]{$f}{10}'), PGML('[`dx`]'), ], [PGML('[`_{}`]'), ], ], align => '*{1}{c}', valign => 'middle',);@]* <<
Now, compute the integrals (we have provided the constants):
>> [@DataTable( [ [PGML('[`_{}`]'), ], [PGML('[_]{$G}{10}'), PGML('[` + c_1 = `]'), PGML('[_]{$F}{10}'), PGML('[` + c_2`]'), ], [PGML('[`_{}`]'), ], ], align => '*{1}{c}', valign => 'middle',);@]* <<
_Don't forget the absolute value on the left antiderivative._
Combine constants and use [`c`] for the final combined constant.
>> [@DataTable( [ [PGML('[`y(x) = `] [_]{$y_gen}{10}'), ], ], align => 'r', valign => 'middle',);@]* <<
END_PGML
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

statement.p: Use y' for the derivative of y in question 2.

p.em: Use c1, c2, c3 as the arbitrary constants of integration.
